problem:
The initial volume of the air pocket $(0.8 \mathrm{p})$

When the water temperature reaches $\theta_2=72.0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, the level difference between the water in the funnel and that in the kettle is $\Delta h=12.1 \mathrm{~mm}$. Derive an expression for the volume of the air pocket $\left(V_{\text {air }, 1}\right)$ in the initial state (at $\left.\theta=\theta_1\right)$ and calculate its numerical value. The gravitational acceleration is $g=9.81 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2$.
solution: The air pocket volume at the beginning of the heating stage can be obtained from the general transformation equation of an ideal gas$\frac{p_{a i r, 1} V_{a i r, 1}}{T_1}=\frac{p_{a i r, 2} V_{a i r, 2}}{T_2},$hence$V_{\text {air }, 1}=\frac{p_{\text {air }, 2}}{p_{\text {air }, 1}} \frac{T_1}{T_2} V_{\text {air }, 2} .$ Initially, the pressure in the air pocket (air and air vapor mixture) is the atmospheric pressure, so$\begin{gathered} p_{\text {air } 1}=p_{\text {air }}\left(T_1\right)=p_0-p_{s v, 1} \\ \left(p_{\text {air } 1}=96.4 \mathrm{kPa}-1.98 \mathrm{kPa}=94.4 \mathrm{kPa}\right) . \end{gathered}$ In the state 2 ,$\begin{gathered} p_{a i r 2}=p_{a i r}\left(T_2\right)=\left(p_0+\rho_{w 2} g \Delta h\right)-p_{s v, 2} \\ \left(p_{a i r 2}=(96.4 \mathrm{kPa}+116 \mathrm{~Pa})-34.0 \mathrm{kPa}=62.5 \mathrm{kPa}\right) . \end{gathered}$ Hence$V_{a i r, 1}=\frac{p_0+\rho_{w 2} g \Delta h-p_{s v, 2}}{p_0-p_{s v, 1}} \frac{T_1}{T_2}\left(V_0-\frac{m_w}{\rho_{w 2}}\right)$and its numerical value is$V_{\text {air }, 1}=\frac{62.5}{94.4} \times \frac{290.45}{345.15} \times 22.8 \mathrm{~cm}^3=12.7 \mathrm{~cm}^3 $.

problem:
The internal energy variation (1.4 p)

Determine a mathematical expression for the internal energy variation of the air trapped in the air pocket $\left(\Delta U_{\text {air } / \text { air pocket }}\right)$, as well as for that of the air in the collector $\left(\Delta U_{\text {air } / \text { collector }}\right)$, during the $\theta_1 \rightarrow$ $\theta_2$ heating process, and calculate their numerical values. The average specific heat of air at constant volume for the temperature range of interest is $c_V=719 \mathrm{~J} /(\mathrm{kg} \cdot \mathrm{K})$ and the molar mass of air is $\mu_{\text {air }}=$ $29.0 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{mol}$.
solution: In the kettle: The air pocket is a closed system. The mass of air is$\begin{gathered} m_{\text {air }}=\frac{p_{\text {air }, 1} V_{\text {air }, 1} \mu_{\text {air }}}{R T_1} \\ \left(m_{\text {air }}=1.44 \cdot 10^{-5} \mathrm{~kg}\right), \end{gathered}$so, the internal energy variation is$\Delta U_{\text {air } / \text { airpocket }}=m_{\text {air }} c_V\left(T_2-T_1\right) \text {, }$having the numerical value$\Delta U_{\text {air } / \text { airpocket }}=0.566 \mathrm{~J} \text {. }$ In the collector: Because the collector is not sealed, the air volume is an open system, so, at any temperature, the Clapeyron-Mendeleev equation is$p_0 V_{\text {collector }}=n R T \text {, }$because the air in the collector is permanently at atmospheric pressure. Since $V_{\text {collector }}$ is also constant, under the assumption that the thermal dilatation of the pot is neglected, then, at any temperature we will have$n T=\text { const. }$ The internal energy variation of the air from the collector is$\Delta U_{\text {air } / \text { collector }}=U_{\text {air } / \text { collector }, 2}-U_{\text {air } / \text { collector }, 1}=\left(n_2 C_V T_2+U_0\right)-\left(n_1 C_V T_1+U_0\right),$so$\Delta U_{\text {air } / \text { collector }}=C_V\left(n_2 T_2-n_1 T_1\right) \text {, }$having the numerical value$\Delta U_{\text {air } / \text { collector }}=0 \mathrm{~J} \text {. }$

problem: The pressure in the air pocket at the end of stage one. As the temperature rises from $\theta_2=72.0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $\theta_3=99.5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, the water is flooding the coffee plug which fills the container of the funnel. The coffee plug has the mass $m_c=6.0 \mathrm{~g}$ and the density of compacted coffee is $\rho_c=1190 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^3$. At $\theta_3=99.5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ the water fills completely the container and this is the end of stage one of coffee brewing. Derive an expression for the pressure $p_3$ above the water in the kettle at $\theta_3=99.5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and calculate its numerical value. For the purpose of this task, neglect the solubility of any coffee component in water, as well as the mass of the water vapors with respect to the total mass of water.
solution: The pressure above the water in the kettle is$p_3=p_{a i r, 3}+p_{s v, 3} \text {, }$where$\begin{gathered} p_{a i r, 3}=\frac{T_3}{T_2} \frac{V_{a i r, 2}}{V_{a i r, 3}} p_{a i r, 2} . \\ \left(p_{a i r, 3}=41.6 \mathrm{kPa} \cong 42 \mathrm{kPa}\right) . \end{gathered}$ The air volume trapped in the kettle at $T_3=372,65 \mathrm{~K}$ is$V_{a i r, 3}=V_0-\left(V_{w 3}-V_f\right) \text {, }$where the water volume is$\begin{gathered} V_{w 3}=\frac{m_w}{\rho_{w 3}} \\ \left(V_{w 3}=62.6 \mathrm{~cm}^3\right) \end{gathered}$and the container volume flooded by water is $ \begin{gathered} V_f=\frac{\pi d^2 h}{4}-\frac{m_c}{\rho_c} . \\ \left(V_f=20 \mathrm{~cm}^3-5,0 \mathrm{~cm}^3=15.0 \mathrm{~cm}^3 \cong 15 \mathrm{~cm}^3 \text { and } V_{\text {air }, 3}=36.6 \mathrm{~cm}^3 \cong 37 \mathrm{~cm}^3\right) . \end{gathered}$ So,$p_3=\frac{T_3}{T_2} \frac{V_0-\frac{m_w}{\rho_{w 2}}}{V_0-\frac{m_w}{\rho_{w 3}}+\frac{\pi d^2 h}{4}-\frac{m_c}{\rho_c}}\left(p_0+\rho_{w 2} g \Delta h-p_{s v, 2}\right)+p_{s v, 3} \text {, }$its numerical value being$p_3=42 \mathrm{kPa}+99.6 \mathrm{kPa}=141.6 \mathrm{kPa} \cong 1.4 \cdot 10^2 \mathrm{kPa}$.

problem:
Stage two: the rise of the water in the collector ( $5.8 \mathrm{p}$ )

This process takes place at the constant temperature $\theta=\theta_3$. The water starts flowing through the filter once the container of the funnel is filled with water and the driver of this process is the pressure difference at the ends of the filter. After the water is transferred to the collector, this second stage of functioning of the moka pot is over. The well-known gurgling sound signals that the coffee brewing is finished. Note: If needed, you can use one of the following pieces of information:
$$
\ln (1+x) \cong x-\frac{x^2}{2}
$$

The relative error made for the above approximation is below $1 \%$ for $x<0.177$.
$$
\begin{gathered}
\int \frac{d x}{x^2(x+a)}=\frac{1}{a^2}\left[\ln \left(1+\frac{a}{x}\right)-\frac{a}{x}\right]+\mathcal{C} \\
\int \frac{d x}{\sqrt{1+a x}}=\frac{2}{a} \sqrt{1+a x}+\mathcal{C} \\
\int \frac{d x}{1+a x}=\frac{1}{a} \ln (1+a x)+\mathcal{C}
\end{gathered}
$$ 
B. 1 The filtration law. When the container of the funnel is loaded with ground coffee, the coffee plug (together with the bordering perforated $\mathrm{Al}$ discs) will act as a cylindrical filter, the properties of which will depend on the dimensions of the coffee grains and the compactness of the coffee plug. The filtration law gives the relationship between the volume flow rate $Q$ of water through the filter and the pressure difference $\Delta p$ on its faces and is similar with Ohm's law in electricity. The hydrodynamic resistance of the filter $\mathcal{R}_h$, similarly to its counterpart in electricity, depends on the area $S$ of the plug's transversal section, its height $h$, but it also depends on the dynamic viscosity coefficient $\eta$ of water and on the so-called filtration coefficient, $k$, also known as the permeability of the filter. Knowing that the filtration coefficient has the dimension of an area and that the measurement unit for $\eta$ in SI is $\mathrm{Pa} \cdot \mathrm{s}$, derive an expression for $\mathcal{R}_h$, as a function of $S, h, k$ and $\eta$, using dimensional analysis. Consider any numeric coefficient equal to one.
solution: The filtration law is$\Delta p=Q \cdot \mathcal{R}_h$and$\mathcal{R}_h=f(\eta, k) \frac{h}{S^{\prime}}$because, in electricity, the electric resistance can be written as$R=\rho \frac{l}{S},$where $\rho$ is the electric resistivity of the given resistor. Then, using dimensional analysis, it follows that$\mathcal{R}_h=C \eta^\alpha k^\beta h S^{-1} \text {, }$with$C=1 \text {, }$as stated in the text. According to the details in the following table, giving the physical quantities, their measurement units in SI and their dimensions \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline $\mathrm{X}$ & $\mathcal{R}_h$ & $s$ & $h$ & $\eta$ & $k$ \\ \hline$\langle X\rangle_{\mathrm{SI}}$ & $\mathrm{Pa} \cdot \frac{\mathrm{s}}{\mathrm{m}^3}=\frac{\mathrm{kg}}{\mathrm{m}^4 \mathrm{~s}}$ & $\mathrm{~m}^2$ & $\mathrm{~m}$ & $\mathrm{~Pa} \cdot \mathrm{s}=\frac{\mathrm{kg}}{\mathrm{m} \cdot \mathrm{s}}$ & $\mathrm{m}^2$ \\ \hline$[X]$ & $\mathrm{L}^{-4} \mathrm{MT}^{-1}$ & $\mathrm{~L}^2$ & $\mathrm{~L}$ & $\mathrm{~L}^{-1} \mathrm{MT}^{-1}$ & $\mathrm{~L}^2$ \\ \hline \end{tabular} the dimensional equation will be:$\mathrm{L}^{-4} \mathrm{MT}^{-1}=\left(\mathrm{L}^{-1} \mathrm{MT}^{-1}\right)^\alpha \mathrm{L}^{2 \beta} \mathrm{L} \cdot \mathrm{L}^{-2},$or, equating the exponents,$\left\{\begin{array}{c} \alpha=1 \\ \beta=-1 \end{array},\right.$hence$\mathcal{R}_h=\frac{\eta h}{k S}$.

problem:
Time evolution of air pressure in the air pocket (1.4 p)

Derive the variation law for the pressure of the air in the air pocket during the second stage of the functioning cycle of the moka pot, as a function of time, $p_{\text {air }}(t)$. For simplicity, consider that the hydrodynamic resistance of the filter is constant during this stage.
solution: The water flowing equation is$p_{a i r}+p_{s v, 3}-p_0=\mathcal{R}_h Q$ Denoting$a=p_{s v, 3}-p_0=3.2 \mathrm{kPa},$the above equation can be written as$p_{a i r}+a=-\mathcal{R}_h \frac{d V}{d t},$because the water volume in the kettle decreases in time. The second stage is, essentially, an isothermal process at $T_3=372.65 \mathrm{~K}$, for which the air volume is$V_0-V=\frac{p_{a i r 3} V_{a i r 3}}{p_{\text {air }}},$where $V$ is the volume occupied by water at that instant. Hence$-\frac{d V}{d t}=-\frac{p_{a i r 3} V_{a i r 3}}{p_{a i r}^2} \frac{d p_{a i r}}{d t},$which gives$p_{\text {air }}+a=-\mathcal{R}_h \frac{p_{\text {air } 3} V_{\text {air } 3}}{p_{\text {air }}^2} \frac{d p_{\text {air }}}{d t} .$ After separating the variables, we get$\frac{d p_{\text {air }}}{p_{\text {air }}^2\left(p_{\text {air }}+a\right)}=-\frac{d t}{\mathcal{R}_h p_{\text {air } 3} V_{\text {air } 3}} .$ Using the integral given at the end of the text, it follows that$\frac{1}{a^2}\left[\ln \left(1+\frac{a}{p_{\text {air }}}\right)-\frac{a}{p_{\text {air }}}\right]=-\frac{t}{\mathcal{R}_h p_{\text {air } 3} V_{\text {air } 3}}+\mathcal{C} $ Since $a=3.2 \mathrm{kPa}$ and $p_{\text {air }}$ varies between $p_{\text {air } 3}=42 \mathrm{kPa}$ and $p_{\text {air } 4}=\frac{p_{\text {air } 3} V_{\text {air } 3}}{V_0}=18.5 \mathrm{kPa} \cong$ $19 \mathrm{kPa}$, this means that the ratio $\frac{a}{p_{\text {air }}}$ varies between 0.076 and 0.17 . Consequently, the logarithm function can be approximated as suggested at the end of the text$\ln (1+x) \cong x-\frac{x^2}{2} \text {, for } x<0.177$so, the above equation can be written as$\frac{1}{2 p_{\text {air }}^2}=\frac{t}{\mathcal{R}_h p_{\text {air } 3} V_{\text {air } 3}}-\mathcal{C} .$ The integration constant can be determined considering that at $t=0 \rightarrow p_{\text {air }}=p_{\text {air } 3}$, so$\mathcal{c}=-\frac{1}{2 p_{\text {air } 3}^2} \text {. }$ As a result,$p_{\text {air }}(t)=p_{\text {air } 3}\left(1+\frac{2 p_{\text {air } 3} t}{\mathcal{R}_h V_{\text {air } 3}}\right)^{-1 / 2}$

problem: The hydrodynamic resistance of the filter filled with coffee $(0.7 \mathrm{p})$ When the container is filled with ground coffee, the water passage through the filter takes the time $\tau_c=54 \mathrm{~s}$. Derive an expression for the hydrodynamic resistance of the filter filled with ground coffee $\left(\mathcal{R}_h\right)$ and calculate its numerical value.
solution: At the end of the stage two, the air pressure in the kettle is $p_{\text {air } 4}$ (with the numerical value given above), so$\mathcal{R}_h=\frac{2 p_{\text {air } 3} \tau_c}{V_{\text {air } 3}\left[\left(\frac{p_{\text {air } 3}}{p_{\text {air } 4}}\right)^2-1\right]} .$ Since$p_{\text {air } 4}=\frac{p_{a i r 3} V_{a i r 3}}{V_0},$then$\mathcal{R}_h=\frac{2 p_{\text {air } 3} \tau_c}{V_{\text {air } 3}\left[\left(\frac{V_0}{V_{\text {air } 3}}\right)^2-1\right]} \text {. }$ Its numerical value is$\mathcal{R}_h=2.9 \cdot 10^{10} \mathrm{~Pa} \cdot \mathrm{s} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-3}$.

problem:
The filtration coefficient of the coffee plug (1.2 p)

When the funnel's container is empty, the passage time of the same quantity of water through this filter is $\tau_0=17 \mathrm{~s}$ and the water transfer through the funnel takes place at the same temperature as in the presence of the coffee plug. Derive an expression for the filtration coefficient of coffee $(k)$ and calculate its numerical value. Assume that the water reaches the base of the funnel's container at the same temperature as above, even if the coffee plug is absent. When the coffee plug is in the container, consider that all the water passing the filter goes through coffee.
solution: From the text, states 1 and 2 are the same, while the state 3 becomes $3^{\prime}$, characterized by$V_{\text {air }, 3}^{\prime}=V_0-\left(V_{w 3}-V_{\text {container }}\right)=84.2 \mathrm{ml}-62.5 \mathrm{ml}+20 \mathrm{ml}=41.7 \mathrm{ml} \cong 42 \mathrm{ml} \text {. }$and$p_3^{\prime}=p_{a i r, 3}^{\prime}+p_{s v, 3},$ where$p_{a i r, 3}^{\prime}=\frac{T_3}{T_2} \frac{V_{a i r, 2}}{V_{a i r, 3}^{\prime}} p_{a i r, 2}=37 \mathrm{kPa} .$ So$p_3^{\prime}=37 \mathrm{kPa}+99,6 \mathrm{kPa}=136.6 \mathrm{kPa} \cong 1.4 \cdot 10^2 \mathrm{kPa} .$ Since the transformation $3 \rightarrow 4$, respectively $3^{\prime} \rightarrow 4^{\prime}$ are isothermal, for the same quantity of air, at the same temperature, and with the same final volume, it means that$p_{\text {air } 4}^{\prime}=p_{\text {air } 4}=19 \mathrm{kPa} \text {. }$ Then$\mathcal{R}_{h 0}=\frac{2 p_{\text {air } 3}^{\prime} \tau_0}{V_{\text {air }, 3}^{\prime}\left[\left(\frac{V_0}{V_{\text {air }, 3}^{\prime}}\right)^2-1\right]}$having the numerical value$\mathcal{R}_{h 0}=9.9 \cdot 10^9 \mathrm{~Pa} \cdot \mathrm{s} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-3} \text {. }$ Because$R_h=R_{h 0}+R_{h, \text { coffee }}$then$R_{h, \text { coffee }}=1.9 \cdot 10^{10} \mathrm{~Pa} \cdot \mathrm{s} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-3} .$ Finally, the filtration coefficient of the used coffee is$k=\frac{\eta h}{R_{h, \text { coffee }} S}=\frac{4 \eta h}{\pi d^2 R_{h, \text { coffee }}},$with the numerical value$k=1.4 \cdot 10^{-13} \mathrm{~m}^2 $.

problem: The work done by the air pocket during the coffee filtration process $(0.8 \mathrm{p})$ Derive an expression for the work done by the air $\left(\mathcal{W}_{\text {air }}\right)$ from the air pocket, as well as for the work done by the water saturated vapors $\left(\mathcal{W}_{s v}\right)$ from the air pocket, respectively, on the water inside the kettle during the filtration process and calculate their numerical values.
solution: The work done by the air during its isothermal expansion is$\mathcal{W}_{\text {air }}=p_{\text {air } 3} V_{\text {air } 3} \ln \frac{V_0}{V_{\text {air } 3}} \text {, }$having the numerical value$\mathcal{W}_{\text {air }}=1.3 \mathrm{~J} \text {. }$ The work done by the saturated vapors is$\mathcal{W}_{s v}=p_{s v, 3} \Delta V=p_{s v, 3}\left(V_0-V_{a i r 3}\right),$with the numerical value$\mathcal{W}_{s v}=99.6 \cdot 10^3 \mathrm{~Pa} \times 47 \cdot 10^{-6} \mathrm{~m}^3=4.7 \mathrm{~J} .$

problem: The work done for circulating the water through the filter to produce coffee infusion (1.0 p) Derive an expression for the work done to pass the water from the kettle through the filter $\left(\mathcal{W}_w\right)$ and calculate its numerical value.
solution: The work done on the water to make it pass through the filter is$\mathcal{W}_w=\int_0^{\tau_c} P d t$where $P$ is the power needed for passing the water through the filter$P=\frac{(\Delta p)^2}{\mathcal{R}_h}=\frac{\left(p_{\text {air }}+a\right)^2}{\mathcal{R}_h}=\frac{a^2}{\mathcal{R}_h}+2 a \frac{p_{\text {air }}}{\mathcal{R}_h}+\frac{p_{\text {air }}^2}{\mathcal{R}_h} .$ Consequently,$\mathcal{W}_w=\frac{a^2}{\mathcal{R}_h} \tau_c+\frac{2 a}{\mathcal{R}_h} \int_0^{\tau_c} p_{\text {air }} d t+\frac{1}{\mathcal{R}_h} \int_0^{\tau_c} p_{\text {air }}^2 d t$and using the time evolution law for $p_{a i r}$, derived at B2, the work is$\mathcal{W}_w=\frac{a^2}{\mathcal{R}_h} \tau_c+\frac{2 a p_{\text {air } 3}}{\mathcal{R}_h} \int_0^{\tau_c}\left(1+\frac{2 p_{\text {air } 3} t}{\mathcal{R}_h V_{\text {air } 3}}\right)^{-1 / 2} d t+\frac{p_{\text {air } 3}^2}{\mathcal{R}_h} \int_0^{\tau_c} \frac{d t}{1+\frac{2 p_{\text {air } 3} t}{\mathcal{R}_h V_{\text {air } 3}}} .$ Finally, using the integrals given at the end of the text, the work becomes  Numerically,$\mathcal{W}_w=1.9 \cdot 10^{-2} \mathrm{~J}+0.30 \mathrm{~J}+1.3 \mathrm{~J}=1.6 \mathrm{~J} \text {. }$

problem:
All the situations studied in the problem take place in an enclosure thermostated at where there is air and saturated water vapor. The pressure in the enclosure is constant and has value $p_0=1,0 \times 10^5 \mathrm{~N} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-2}$.

Write all the numerical results obtained using two significant digits.
In solving the problem, you can use the following physical constants:
$$
\begin{aligned}
& g=9,8 \mathrm{~m} \cdot \mathrm{s}^{-2} \\
& \mu_0=4 \pi \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{H} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-1} \\
& \varepsilon_0=8,9 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{~F} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$
as well as the following data on the physical properties of water.
Data Table
\begin{tabular}{|l|c|}
\hline Density & $\rho=1,0 \times 10^3 \mathrm{~kg} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-3}$ \\
\hline Saturated vapor pressure at $70^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ & $p_s=3,1 \times 10^4 \mathrm{~N} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-2}$ \\
\hline Surface tension coefficient at $70^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ & $\sigma=6,5 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~N} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-1}$ \\
\hline Magnetic susceptibility $\left(\chi=\mu_r-1\right)$ & $\chi=-9,0 \times 10^{-6}$ \\
\hline
\end{tabular} For the first, part of the problem, you will study the falling with a constant speed of water droplets . An ultra-fast, enlarged, photograph shows that the falling water droplet remains approximately spherical, retains its symmetry of rotation around the vertical axis but undergoes a slight elongation along this axis, reaching a length $2 h=2,0 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}$ (measured by along the axis of vertical symmetry). At the ends of the longitudinal axis of symmetry of the droplet, the radii of curvature of its surface are respectively $R_1=h-\delta$ and $R_2=h+\delta$ with $\delta=7,5 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~m}$. Using the data obtained from the ultraf ast photo and physical quantities indicated in the statement, determines the value of $\sigma$ - the surface tension coefficient of water.
solution: $\begin{aligned} & p_{\text {up }}+p_{\text {hidro }}=p_{\text {down }} \\ & \sigma=\frac{\rho \cdot g \cdot h \cdot\left(h^2-\delta^2\right)}{2 \delta} \quad \sigma \cong \frac{\rho \cdot g \cdot h^3}{2 \delta}\end{aligned}$ $\sigma=6.5 \times 10^{-2} N \cdot m^{-1}$

problem:
A stalagmometer is a device used for investigating the surface tension of liquids. The device is a glass tube whose middle section is widened. The lower end of the tube is narrowed and continues with a metallic capillary tube (like a needle), to force the fluid to fall out of the tube as a droplet. The fluid flows slowly from the tube in a vertical direction. Denote with $R$ the radius of the drop hanging below the nozzle, which grows slowly in time until the drop separates from the nozzle due to the gravitation. When the droplet separates from the tube, the liquid surface forms in the vicinity of the nozzle a "neck", which has vertical tangent.

There is water in a vertically positioned stalagmometer. The metal capillary has an inside diameter $d=1,0 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}$ and negligible wall thickness. The level difference between the upper surface of the water in the stalagmometer and the lower end of the capillary is constant and equal to $H=5,0 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~m}$. In the calculations, use the value of the surface tension that you obtained in the previous part of the problem. If you did not solve the previous part, use the value indicated in the data table. Determine the expression of radius $R$ of the spherical droplet that detaches from the end of the capillary tube, neglecting the contribution due to the hydrostatic pressure of the water in the stalagmometer tube. Calculate the value of radius $R$
solution: $G=F_\sigma \quad R=\sqrt[3]{\frac{3 \cdot d \cdot \sigma}{4 \cdot g \cdot \rho}}$ $R=7.9 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}$

problem: Determine the expression of radius $R_H$ of the spherical drop that detaches from the end of the capillary tube, considering the contribution due to the hydrostatic pressure of the water in the stalagmometer. Calculate the value of radius $R_H$.
solution: $G+F_H=F_\sigma \quad\left\{\begin{array}{l}R_H=\sqrt[3]{\frac{3}{4}\left(\frac{d \cdot \sigma}{\rho \cdot g}-\frac{d^2 \cdot H}{4}\right)} \\ R_H=R \cdot \sqrt[3]{1-\frac{d \cdot H \cdot \rho \cdot g}{4 \sigma}}\end{array}\right.$ $R_H=7.4 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}$

problem: The metallic capillary of the stalagmometer described in part B is put in contact with an electric source and acquires the increasing electric potential $\phi$. The water in the stalagmometer is electrically conductive. Determine the expression of the pressure $p_{\varepsilon}$, determined by the electrostatic charge, inside the spherical water drop having the radius $R$ at the end of the tube, as a function of the electric potential $\phi$. Neglects the electrostatic interaction between the drop and the rest of the system.
solution: The variation of the volume of the conductive drop, if its radius increases with the infinitely small amount $\Delta R$\Delta V=\frac{4 \pi}{3} \cdot\left[(R+\Delta R)^3-R^3\right] \cong 4 \pi \cdot R^2 \cdot \Delta R$ Variation of the capacitance of the spherical capacitor represented by the drop $\Delta C=4 \pi \cdot \varepsilon_0 \cdot \Delta R$  The variation of the electrostatic energy, accumulated in the drop at the constant potential $\Delta W_{\varepsilon}=2 \pi \cdot \varepsilon_0 \cdot \phi^2 \cdot \Delta R$  Mechanical work $L_{\varepsilon}$ of electrostatic pressure $p_{\varepsilon}$, when increasing the volume with $\Delta V$\left\{\begin{array}{l} L_{\varepsilon}=p_{\varepsilon} \cdot \Delta V \\ L_{\varepsilon}=p_{\varepsilon} \cdot 4 \pi \cdot R^2 \cdot \Delta R \end{array}\right.$\Delta W_{\varepsilon}=L_{\varepsilon}$ $p_{\varepsilon}=\frac{\varepsilon_0 \cdot \phi^2}{2 R^2}$

problem: When the increasing electrostatic potential of the tube reaches the value $\phi_{\max }$ for which the pressure determined by the surface tension is equal in the module of the electrostatic pressure, the water drop having the radius $R$ breaks and its content is sprayed. Determine the expression $\phi_{\max }$ of the potential of the metal tube for which the water droplet is sprayed. Express the result as a function of $R, \sigma$ and physical constants. Calculate the numerical value of this potential for the water droplet having radius $R=1,0 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}$.
solution: The expression of the pressure exerted towards the outside of the drop, just before the moment of its spraying$p_{\varepsilon}=\frac{\varepsilon_0 \cdot \phi_{\max }^2}{2 R^2}$ The expression of the pressure exerted towards the inside of the drop $p_\sigma=\frac{2 \sigma}{R}$\begin{aligned} & p_\sigma=p_{\varepsilon} \\ & \phi_{\max }=2 \cdot \sqrt{\frac{\sigma \cdot R}{\varepsilon_0}} \\ & \phi_{\max }=5.4 \times 10^3 \mathrm{~V} \end{aligned}$

problem: Assume that when spraying the water droplet separates into $n=64$ identical spherical droplets. Determine the expression of $p_\pi$ - the pressure leading to the spherical shape of the droplets formed by spraying. Express the result as a function of $R, \sigma$ and physical constants. Calculate the numerical value of the pressure $p_\pi$.
solution: The pressure due to the surface tension in each of the $n$ small drops$p_{\sigma \pi}=\frac{2 \sigma}{r} \quad p_{\sigma \pi}=\frac{2 \sigma}{R} \cdot \sqrt[3]{n}$ The electrostatic potential of each small drop $\frac{R}{n} \cdot \phi_{\max }=r \cdot \phi_\pi$\phi_\pi=\frac{1}{\sqrt[3]{n^2}} \cdot 2 \cdot \sqrt{\frac{\sigma \cdot R}{\varepsilon_0}} \quad \phi_\pi=2 \cdot \sigma^{1 / 2} \cdot \varepsilon_0^{-1 / 2} \cdot R^{1 / 2} \cdot n^{-2 / 3}$ The outward pressure determined by the electric charges on each small drop$p_{\varepsilon \pi}=\frac{\varepsilon_0 \cdot \phi_\pi^2}{2 r^2} \quad p_{\varepsilon \pi}=\frac{2 \sigma}{R} \cdot n^{-2 / 3}$ Expression of the pressure leading to the spherical shape of the droplets resulting from the spray $\quad p_\pi=\frac{2 \sigma}{R} \cdot\left(n^{1 / 3}-n^{-2 / 3}\right)$p_\pi=5.1 \times 10^2 N \cdot m^{-2}$

problem:
Water is a diamagnetic substance. Its introduction into a magnetic field leads to the appearance of magnetic dipoles that are equivalent to magnets having the opposite polarity to that of the applied magnetic field. As a result, when in an inhomogeneous magnetic field, water tends to leave the place with a more intense magnetic field.

A region of the vacuum is situated in the magnetic field with induction $\vec{B}$. The density of energy in that region has the value $w_0$. When there is water in that region, the density of energy is $w_w$. Write the expression $\Delta w=w_w-w_0$ for the difference in energy densities as a function of $\vec{B}, \mu_0, \mu_r$.
solution: $\Delta W=W_w-w_0=\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\mu_r}-1\right)$

problem: The water in a glass vessel is subjected to the action of a non-uniform magnetic field with a vertical direction. The point $M$ is on the same vertical as the point $N$, belowit. The induction of the magnetic field has the modulus $|\vec{B}|$ at the point $M$ and the modulus 0 at the point $N$. Imagine that a small volume of water $v$ is moved from point $M$ to point $N$ and then brought back from point $N$ to point $M$. Comparing the magnetic potential energy for the initial and final states of the water volume $v$ determines the expression of the pressure difference (due to the existence of the inhomogeneous magnetic field) between the points $N$ and $M$.
solution: $\begin{aligned} & \Delta W=v \cdot \frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\mu_r}-1\right) \\ & L=v \cdot\left(p_N-p_M\right) \\ & v \cdot\left(p_N-p_M\right)=v \cdot \frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\mu_r}-1\right) \\ & p_N-p_M=\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\mu_r}-1\right)\end{aligned}$

problem: A vertical graduated cylinder of glass (a mensure) $\mathbb{V}$ with length $\mathbb{L}=4,0 \times 10^{-1} \mathrm{~m}$ is filled in three quarters with water. A solenoid is wound on its lower half. The solenoid generates inside it a uniformly vertical magnetic field having the induction modulus $B=K \cdot I$. In expression $I$ is the intensity of the electric current flowing through the solenoid and $K=5,0 \times 10^{-2} T \cdot A^{-1}$ is a constant of device. It assumes that due to the scattering of field lines the magnetic field outside the solenoid is negligible. Determine the expression of intensity of the electrical current through the solenoid so that the water in the vessel $\mathbb{V}$ would start to boil. Calculate the value of this intensity of the electrical current
solution: $\begin{aligned} & p_N=p_0+\rho \cdot g \cdot \frac{\mathbb{L}}{4} \cong p_0 \\ & p_M=p_0-\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\mu_r}-1\right) \\ & p_M=p_s \quad p_s=p_s\left(70^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right) \\ & I=\sqrt{-\frac{2 \mu_0 \cdot(1+\chi) \cdot\left(p_0-p_s\right)}{K^2 \cdot \chi}} \\ & I=2.7 \times 10^3 \mathrm{~A}\end{aligned}$

problem: The gas bubbles that appear during boiling rise to the free surface of the water. Consider that there are only water-saturated vapors in the bubbles and that the radius of a bubble remains constant as it rises. Consider a vapor bubble with a constant radius $R_{\text {bubble }}=1,0 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}$, which rises on the distance $h_0=1,0 \cdot 10^{-1} \mathrm{~m}$, with a constant speed $v_{\text {bubble }}$. Determine the expression of the mechanical work $L_{\text {bubble }}$ done by the vapor bubble on the water in the vessel $\mathbb{V}$, during its lifting. Express the result as function of $R_{\text {bubble }}, h_0$ and $v_{\text {bubble }}$.
solution: $L_{\text {bubble }}=\pi \cdot R_{\text {bubble }}^2 \cdot h_0 \cdot \rho \cdot \frac{v_{\text {bubble }}^2}{2}$

problem: Determine the value of time interval $t_{u p}$, in which the bubble reaches the free surface of the water in the vessel $\mathbb{V}$.
solution: $F_{\text {asc }}=\frac{4 \pi}{3} \cdot R_{\text {butb }}^3 \cdot g \cdot \rho \quad$ Note: the weight of the vapor is negligible$F_{\text {dis }}=\pi \cdot R_{\text {butbel }}^2 \cdot \rho \cdot \frac{v_{\text {bubble }}^2}{2}$\vec{F}_{\text {asc }}+\vec{F}_{\text {dis }}=0 \quad v_{\text {bubble }}=\sqrt{\frac{8 g \cdot R_{\text {bubble }}}{3}}$ $t_{u p}=\frac{h_0}{\sqrt{\frac{8 g \cdot R_{\text {bubble }}}{3}}}$ $t_{u p}=6.2 \times 10^{-1} \mathrm{~s}$
